Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2009 06:22AM marshakb wrote: Robyn, Aredia is the older version of Zometa.  The main difference is the infusion time.  Aredia takes 2 hours to infuse and Zometa only 15 minutes.  That is how it was explained to me.  Before my medicaid was approved I went to the hospital for infusion and they automatically substitute with Aredia (it is cheaper).  Now I get infused at my cancer center and do the 15 minute Zometa.  Side effects are about the same with both.  12 hours or so after infusion you will feel flu like symptoms.  Chills, achy all over, feverish then boom, you feel fine the next day.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2007 05:05AM marshakb wrote: Vick....I too had no health insurance and their are programs out there to help. Mine was a local group through our American Medical Society and it deals with women with no insurance, kinda the kind that fall thru the cracks. You can't be on any government assistance, that was one of the criteria for me, but I was approved for the program (ours is called We Care) and this program is with docs in town who donate their services. It is a huge tax right off for them. They can "bill" at full price and write it off on their taxes so alot of them do this instead of pro bono work as long as it goes thru a charity organization. Check around but start with you local medical society. Every county in Florida has one, not sure about other states. Hugs, Marsha

When I started having sciatic nerve pain in my leg, I was SURE it was just good ole common aging like everybody else has. I thought "Positive" and was getting on with my llife. What bullshit. Hugs to you!

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2009 09:44AM marshakb wrote: Phoenix, could you be more specific?  SSI is based on household income.  It is an assistance program for families who fall below the poverty level.  SSDI is based on being disabled and being able to draw the social security (you've paid in over the years) early.  So these are two very different things.  Has your home situation changed?  Income-wise?   People who draw disability (SSDI) do so because they can no longer work and the household relied on that income.   There are programs out there aside from "government" who help cancer patients.  Badboob67 has a whole list of them.  Click on her name and she has a link that she has compiled of organizations who help.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2009 05:52PM marshakb wrote: I had nerve pain with my femur bone mets. No one thought it was cancer related. I felt like your garden variety sciatic nerve. Went to pcp, chiropractor, massage therapy, etc. Had temporary relief but that is all. What alot of people don't understand is you can have NO pain from the actual tumor but it makes that bone weak and you get related pain, like my sciatic or over use of a muscle/tendon pain. It WAS the sciatic nerve that caused the pain because it was exposed and rubbing against the crumpling bone. I'm not trying to scare you but pain lasting that long needs to be checked out with a PET/CT scan. Praying it is nothing!

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2007 03:00PM marshakb wrote: Why did she think stage 4? Are you sure he didn't say BIRAD 4? This means highly supicious of bc, which it was he said, right? That is about aggression and the biopsy doen't show that until the path results are back. So you will know that tommorow. Stage 4 also means it has spread to other areas of the body and they would need PET/CT scans, MRI, bone scan etc. I think you misunderstood something. To be stage 4 the nodes would most likely be involved. Let us know what you find out from the pathology and maybe we can help you figure it out. You're a good friend! Marsha

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 07:34AM marshakb wrote: Jennifer, it is NOT hard to get on disability.  Stage IV is an automatic approval.   Just keep in mind that you have to go 5 months from the time you stop working for it to take effect.  You do not get back pay for that 5 months.  There is a very good thread here on the mets forum about SSDI.  Also medicare is NOT automatic with disability.  It will kick in 2 years after your disability is approved.  My 5 month wait time is up the end of this month.  So I qualify for my SSDI check for June but they pay in arrears so my first check arrives in July.   6 months with no pay is not easy to do!

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2007 07:41AM marshakb wrote: Rose....unfortunately we sometimes have to push our doctors to take our concerns more seriously. No one was suggesting she get a knife and biopsy herself, but my primary doc said IMMEDIATELY that the indention is almost always an indication of something that should not be there. I'm just not willing to put my life on the line and trust that every doc is God and knows everything. Being knowledgable about BC and signs and symptoms usually will make your docs respond to you better and at least do follow up to relieve the anxiety of not knowing. Yes, maybe she needs a new doc, but the analogy you used that questioning a doctors opinion is like picking up a knife and doing your own surgery is extreme. Like Vicki said, sometimes we have to be pushy, it is our bodies after all. Marsha

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2008 06:00PM marshakb wrote: Hey Ladies, I'm Marsha from the Feb Chemo Cruisers.  Just wanted to stop in and give you all some encouragement.  Before you know it, this will be past you, one day you will wake up and think "what the hell just happened to me" and it will truly feel like some kind of oddball dream.  The Feb Chemo Cruisers of 07 are getting together Feb 08 in Florida at a beach house, you know why?  Cause we made the best friends of our life right here on these threads!  The journey sucked, no kidding you there, but the hair grows back, your energy level returns, your taste buds wake back up, and the shock of sitting in that chemo chair the first time subsides. Hugs to you all, I remember when we first started and someone came on from a year previous and it gave me hope that one day I would do the same.  Marsha
Posts.Title: Jan 2008--Ain't it Great? Determined1 Diana63

Posts.Content: marshakb wrote: I am so tired of sitting in this house!  I had the rod put in my femur Dec 20 and have finally graduated to crutches.  Slowly but surely I am getting out more and more.  I went to a friends party a couple of weeks ago and managed to stay until 10 pm (Yahoo, what a party animal, LOL).  My parents came to visit last week, I let my mom take me shopping (wheelchair shopping is sooooo hard to do) and out for an early birthday dinner.  (Even had an Italian Margarita).  My birthday (which I now WANT to have) was yesterday so 8 of my girlfriends have 2 cabins rented on the river for a birthday weekend.  I can't wait!  One of my friends who we call a whoo whoo woman,  she teachs yoga, meditation, crystal healing etc etc is bringing all her goodies.  Another is a message therapist who is bringing her table.  Another is a first class cook.  All I have to bring is my sense of humor! I guess once the shock wears off and some of the body starts to heal there is life with a stage IV diagnosis.   I have a need for laughter in my life.  You know, like getting the church giggles where you laugh so hard you almost pee your pants?  Or start making those hiccup noises?  Well I laughed my way thru the first dx (mostly anyway) and I sure would like to try doing that again!   I'm really thinking about taking the plunge and actually plan a vacation, IN ADVANCE AND PAYING FOR IT!!! Thanks for letting me share.   Look out "life' I'm back and I plan to live it! (Somebody remind me of that if necessary in the future hahaha)  This does not mean I can't "bitch" every once in awhile.  LOL I'm not dead yet! Dx ILC, Stage IV, 1/13 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
